The incomplete transformation of Syria's Ahmad al-Sharaa, Islamist rebel turned president
subhead: 'Syria after al-Assad' (1/5). The man who toppled Syria's Baathist regime has succeeded in breaking the country's international isolation. Yet the former jihadist, who governs with a handful of loyal followers, has struggled to defuse the sectarian and ethnic tensions left by the civil war.

title: Europeans stunned and challenged by new US security strategy
Louvre unions call strike over work conditions and need for building repairs
EU governments back 'return hubs' in tightening of migration policy
subhead: Interior ministers of European Union member states approved a slate of measures on Monday that include the creation of centers outside EU borders for sending away irregular migrants. Parliament must now consider whether to approve the measures.

title: French PM and Socialists raise the stakes ahead of key social security budget vote
subhead: The Assemblée Nationale is set to vote on a key social security budget bill on December 9. Socialist leader Olivier Faure has called for backing the bill. If rejected, there would be major consequences for the country and the prime minister.

title: 'The Trump-Infantino farce shows how FIFA debases football'
subhead: The awarding of a 'peace prize' to US President Donald Trump during the 2026 World Cup draw epitomizes how the international federation has hijacked football for its own ends, writes Le Monde columnist Jérôme Latta.

title: Cocaine overtakes cannabis as France's most sold drug
subhead: With a value of €3.1 billion compared to €2.7 billion for cannabis, cocaine has become the leading illicit drug market in France, according to a French drugs observatory study.

When Christmas presents are secondhand: 'My sisters looked at me strangely'
subhead: Far from consumerist extravaganzas like 'Black Friday' or 'Cyber Monday,' some people in France prefer to turn to secondhand and recycled goods for their holiday shopping. Juggling the risks of technical failure and the fear of being seen as 'cheapskates,' they share their experiences.

title: Martin Parr, extraordinary photographer of the ordinary, dies at 73
subhead: Famed worldwide for his saturated images capturing leisure society, the British photographer died of cancer on Saturday at the age of 73.

title: The lawyer suing far-right French mayors for setting up Nativity scenes
subhead: French courts have repeatedly ruled that installing Nativity scenes in town halls is a breach of the 1905 law separating the churches and the state. Sophie Mazas works tirelessly to ensure the principle of 'laïcité' is enforced.
